bibl.title: New Literary Texts from Amheida, Ancient Trimithis (Dakhla Oasis, Egypt).
bibl.note: The archaeological context (P.D.). - The texts (R.Cr.). - A fourth-century private residence which belonged to an upper-class family and adjacent to it a school building. The inscriptions of rooms 19 and 13 include a few lines from the Odyssey (δ 221-223), what appears to be the reworking of a passage from Plutarch's Moralia (334 B) and a few words from Euripides' Hypsipyle (P. Oxy. VI, 852 [= M.-P.3 438; LDAB 957], fr. 60).
bibl.seg: 241 Trimithis 364 Euripides Homerus Plutarchus Chaeronensis Scholastica 810 910.4
Raffaella Cribiore & Paola Davoli, New Literary Texts from Amheida, Ancient Trimithis (Dakhla Oasis, Egypt).

The archaeological context (P.D.). - The texts (R.Cr.). - A fourth-century private residence which belonged to an upper-class family and adjacent to it a school building. The inscriptions of rooms 19 and 13 include a few lines from the Odyssey (δ 221-223), what appears to be the reworking of a passage from Plutarch's Moralia (334 B) and a few words from Euripides' Hypsipyle (P. Oxy. VI, 852 [= M.-P.3 438; LDAB 957], fr. 60).
